title: Between 1 January 2019 and 31 December 2019, will an armed group from Myanmar engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Myanmar?
preds: Taking it down to base rate.

http://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/2019/feb/05/northeast-rebels-flee-camps-after-myanmar-army-offensive-1934746.html With the news that the rebels have fled from government forces, I'm slashing my prediction of violence from 32 to 7.

So, in the two weeks, they have decided to strike the Arakan Army and label them terrorists. It looks like this is going to be more limited, and since they represent Buddhists, it might not involve the same kind of violence on civilian populations. I'm taking it down by half and see what happens over the next two weeks.
the roatinger have no power and are very poor. they have no arms to make a compaign. the gouvernment has the oposition of the occidental countries. I think nothing special will occur in Myanmar

http://www.atimes.com/article/a-new-war-rages-in-myanmar/ Moderating my last prediction down from 45% to 32%,  although some serious violence is to be expected, it's not clear how far this will affect the local population.   If further reports are released in the weeks/months ahead, I will reassess the probabilities.
No one there seems to be able to count. Suu Kyi knows China has her back - and info not very transparent. Will 1000 or more be killed? Probably. Will it be reported? Unlikely.

Early Warning base rate is 5.4% Genocide Watch calls it an emergency. ACLED civilian data for the last year is single digits per month. However, this article talking about crushing terrorists and India deportations suggest genocide is a real possibility this year. "The insurgents killed 13 policemen and wounded nine in attacks on four police posts on Friday, as Myanmar celebrated Independence Day, state media reported...An Arakan Army spokesman outside Myanmar told Reuters last week the group attacked the security forces in response to a broad military offensive in northern Rakhine State that also targeted civilians. "

https://frontiermyanmar.net/en/myanmar-army-to-launch-crackdown-on-rakhine-rebels-govt  - AFP reports today that the Government has announced a further military crackdown on alleged rebels in the Rakhine state, where the previous civilian killings have occurred.    https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/burma-rohingya-muslims-crackdown-government-crackdown-campaign-reuters-un-report-a7570116.html - During the last crackdown in 2017, the civilians killed was cited as "over 1,000" rather than any higher threshold (e.g. over 2 or 3 thousand). It's not clear from some quick research how many civilians remain in the state after many were displaced, and it may be that the majority of the civilians (especially from the group most likely to be targeted, the Rohingyas) have already fled. One exacerbating factor may be the pressure from Bangladesh to repatriate those who fled over the border, as well as ongoing hostility from non-Rohingyas in Rakhine state: https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-46312889 The news of the fresh crackdown in Rakhine certainly indicates that violence will take place, but it is difficult from open sources to assess how many civilians are in the affected area, and I further expect that whatever happens will be hard for the outside world to verify unless it is on a very large scale.
Been there, done that, so the "need" no longer exists. Rohingya are staying put in Bangladesh, not returning.
